channel.title: The bot's canvas
channel.description:
well, my friend and i are making a bot as we've got too much free time :P we've done a fair bit of shit, but we're currently having a problem with the canvas being over our menu. I know this has to do with the games canvas being heavyweight so it'd appear above our lightweight menu strip stuff. So, would there be anyway to fix this? I was thinking of using a buffered image to take a continuous picture of the canvas, and adding that to our TabbedPane instead of getting the applet directly, but i dont exactly get the whole super.getGraphics() part.
We currently are just xbooting the canvashack.jar, but if we were going to use a buffered image, we'd need to paint on that (im guessing). I'd appreciate anyones help if they can help with with my problems.

item.title: The bot's canvas
item.dc:creator: @Killer-99-pkz Killer-99-pkz
item.description:
@Killer-99-pkz wrote:

drop the focus from the canvas to the menu, its not going to done automaticly since rs makes the canvas request focus if it doesent have it and it could have it so typing and clicking dont get messed up… i may be rong… but give it a try.

if it flashes when you try to open a menu, then im probably right. another thing to add to this, you should be more careful about these menus, they could easily make a repaint monitoring system that points out the menus where popped up. easily done just with a little logic and you guys would have a problem. the only way to fix that would be to temporarly disable repaint reflection until the menu is closed then send a full repaint (mimicing switching windows). but i doubt they would ever do it anyway.

Read full topic

item.title: The bot's canvas
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

Take a step back and think about what it is you want to do. If your main focus is to, by golly, get that menu to show up then by all means jump down this diverting rabbit hole until you solve the issue. If the menu is merely a tiny nice-to-have feature of a much more impressive botting framework then, well, why do you have a menu again?

Why not integrate the ‘menu’ within the game itself? Why not create a HUD menu instead of using, I assume, a swing-based menu? If done right you’ll accomplish two things:

[ul][li]You’ll learn quite a bit about how the game works internally[/li]
[li]You’ll have a menu that looks far better than something Rahul in QA can do with 2 months of coding experience[/li][/ul]

This reminds me somewhat of the US Congress crucifying MLB players for steroid use… apparently all of the problems in the USA are solved; All the poor have been fed. All the budgets have been balanced. All the corruption has been rectified. All peace has been restored. Now, Congress can focus on what really matters: Steroid use in professional sports.

Maybe focus less on things that matter less. In no way is this an insult, I find myself doing the same thing. Focus on mapping out the game and figuring out what everything does before really caring if a menu-that-doesnt-really-do-a-whole-lot-anyway can display over the canvas or not. Otherwise, you and your friend will have a pretty swing app hosting an applet that has a menu that can open a file and exit and not much else rather than a botting framework that really works consistently.

Just a thought.

Read full topic

item.title: The bot's canvas
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

Add the applet to a JPanel. Dispose the Canvas’s peer and override Canvas getGraphics() method to paint on the JPanel in the appropriate place. Dah dah: lightweight runescape.

Read full topic
